Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Switching-Free DC Voltage Conversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be the introduction of a revolutionary new technology for electrical components affected by electrical noise, electromagnetic interference, large footprint, and high bill of materials costs associated with certain components. This will have a major impact for noise-sensitive circuits in demanding military, medical and communication applications. The dramatically reduced footprint and component count will enable smaller, lighter and lower-cost electronic circuits, positively impacting a wide range of technologies, such as portable consumer electronics and Internet-of-Things devices. The unique innovation developed in the project will enable integrated circuits with improved performance at lower heating and higher system efficiencies. This novel technology can be manufactured with existing processes, enabling high volume, reliable and low-cost commercial components.

The proposed project will create the first demonstration of a voltage regulator circuit able to provide efficient voltage up-conversion and down-conversion without switching. The technology uses photons to multiply or divide voltage within a novel voltage regulator architecture. The research will address the main technical challenges to achieving high efficiency, including photon generation, photon transfer and conversion to electricity within optoelectronic devices. Minimizing optical and electrical losses is crucial to achieving a high efficiency voltage regulator circuit, critical to many DC-DC conversion applications. The research will study non-radiative losses in semiconductor light emitters, photon management strategies to reduce optical loss, and electrical device design to minimize carrier collection and series resistance losses. Finally, these aspects will be combined into a fully functional voltage regulator circuit, aiming to demonstrate purely DC voltage up-conversion with efficiencies as high as 85%. To accomplish this, the project uses advanced optoelectronic device design and modeling, commercial epitaxy, advanced compound semiconductor fabrication, semiconductor material and device characterization, and analog circuit modeling and development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DC voltage conversion is a vital operation in a wide range of electronics systems, where inputs from batteries or power supplies are routinely converted into specific DC voltages used to power a wide range of components. There are two common devices in use today for DC-DC conversion: switching regulators and linear voltage regulators. Switching regulators can be highly efficient but are plagued by electrical switching noise and electromagnetic interference (EMI). In noise sensitive applications, additional noise filtering circuitry and EMI shielding is required, which increases component count, footprint and cost. Linear regulators are simple and low-noise alternatives requiring fewer components but cannot boost voltage and are inefficient for large voltage steps, limiting their usefulness. Polaris Semiconductor has invented a linear regulator device which can perform two functions no other linear regulator can: 1) pure DC voltage boosting and 2) efficiently stepping down large voltage differences. This creates a device with the simplicity, compactness and noise performance of a linear regulator but which has the functionality of a switching regulator. This can have a revolutionary impact on applications where excellent EMI performance, minimal size and low weight are key performance criteria, such as defense microsystems, medical devices, industrial internet-of-things (IIoT) and wearable consumer electronics. The key innovation in our approach is a highly efficient optocoupler device, combined with a novel circuit design which enables unique functionality in a linear regulator architecture.

In Phase I, in collaboration with the Ohio State University (OSU), Arizona State University (ASU) and epitaxy foundry IQE, Polaris Semiconductor has proven the concept behind the invention, creating experimental demonstrations of each key component of our technology. Our project has created devices with previously unseen capabilities and paving the way for exciting custom integrated circuit (IC) development in Phase II. We have designed, grown and fabricated a new type of optocoupler device with >51% efficiency, unparalleled in any previous demonstration, and numerous breadboard circuits for up-conversion and down-conversion. A clear pathway to optocoupler efficiencies exceeding 60% exists with further improvements to our device design. This will enable future voltage regulator circuits for up-conversion and down conversion with efficiency in the range of 65-90%, depending on the voltage step.

The accompanying figure shows a photograph of novel Polaris Semiconductor optocoupler devices wire-bonded to a ceramic chip carrier, which was subsequently built into novel breadboard circuits. Breadboard regulator circuit examples were built for several combination, including for a down-conversion configuration between 3.3V to 1.8V. A peak efficiency of 72% was achieved, which is a 37% relative increase over a conventional linear regulator over the same voltage step. A related circuit was also built for buck conversion between roughly 5V and 1.8V which demonstrated a 69% relative increase over a conventional linear regulator. Pure DC up-conversion over a range from approximately 1.5V to 2.35V has also been demonstrated with a peak efficiency exceeding 62%. Switching-free DC voltage conversion with such high efficiency has not been demonstrated previously, and significant improvements can be made beyond this proof-of-concept demonstration using our approach.

Our R&D has clearly demonstrated that our technological approach is physically sound, technically feasible and can be commercialized entirely using growth, fabrication and assembly procedures already employed at scale. The deep understanding we have gained of the underlying device physics, process development details, circuit integration strategies and quantitative device performance prediction abilities place our technical team in an excellent position to advance our prototype development from breadboard prototypes to packaged components. This will bring our technology close to a commercial product, but our R&D proposal will also allow our team to realize improvements in performance, functionality, and cost, building on our existing designs and processes. These developments will give our technology the chance to be truly disruptive in the power management IC arena, in both our beachhead market and beyond.
